moves.2... c6: over 11.000 times played on gameknot. Little favourable for white.
moves.3. Nf3: Not most common, most favourable for white as well(according to chess database)
moves.4. e3: not most common, a little more favourable than the most common move for white.
moves.4... Bg4: Not most common, relatively favourable for white. From now of this is called the queen gambit declined, 4 e3.
moves.5. cxd5: not most common, 5th in the list of the chess database.
moves.6. Bd3: move that not is earlier played in this position on gameknot. So here is stopping my commentary about the chess database.
moves.6... Nc6: making knight active, attacking d4, which is defended.
moves.7. O-O: rochading when it is possible and it is relatively quiet.
moves.8. dxe5: I cant doing something else as accepting pawn offer
moves.8... Nxe5: completing pawn offer, making a fork between bishop and knight, which is not dangerous.
moves.9... Nc6: Must do something to turn the check away.
moves.10. Nc3: defending bishop, I think, cant very good remember.
moves.10... Bc5: uh, making bishop active and preparing castling??
moves.11. Qa4: making queen active and defending bishop, dont remember at the moment why defending bishop exactly, which is not attacked.
moves.12. Bxc6+: He expected I took the bishop I think, but I take the knight first. So he need a move to get my bishop and I have space to do something else.
moves.13. Qxc6+: making a fork between rook and king.
moves.14. gxf3: And eventually I take the bishop. So I have a material gain of one point.
moves.15... Bxd4: taking pawn back and attacking my other knight.
moves.16. Re1+: making check, he must do something about that first.
moves.18. Qxd4: and taking bishop, bnow material gain of 4 points.
moves.20. Bxd4: and completing queen offer and attacking knight in this way.
moves.21. Bxa7: taking pawn. Looks very fool, when you see the rook, but when he should do Rxa7, I should do Re8, checkmate.
moves.21... h6: creating a way for the king in case of emergency.
moves.22. Bb6: taking bishop out of the attack from the rook.
moves.22... Kh7: already running away over his new emergency way.
moves.24... Rc8: attacking bishop with the other rook.
moves.25... Ra7: running away and attacking bishop for the second time.
moves.26... Ra6: attacking bishop again, when I remove bishop, that rook is attacking my rook, that is undefended in that case.
moves.28. a5: defending bishop, which is defending the pawn.
moves.28... Nh5: running back?? I dont know what is the planning. I think he wasted 2 moves.
moves.29... Rc2: dont like the little game in the corner anymore and attacks the pawn.
moves.30... Rxc7: taking the knight, that is attacking the rook. He must offer 2 points.
moves.31. Bxc7: taking rook, gained 2 points. Totally 7 points now.
moves.32... f6: running away, to stay in defence of the pawn at g7 that is in defence of the king.
moves.33. Re5: looks risky. It is. It looks like a blunder. It is. I was forgotten the pawn at a 5. When it wasnt there, this was a good move. I cant explain exactly. Are there volunteers that can explain in a comment??
moves.35. Rd8: running away and attacking rook that is very isolated and undefended.
moves.39. Bb6: challenging for an offer between pawn and knight.
moves.39... Kg6: maybe running away for the case I promote??
moves.40. b4: challenging, when he takes that undefended pawn I can promote. Here he resigned. I hope you have enjoyed reading this and learned something.
